heisig_chinese_memo: To me, this hanzi looks like a person with two arms and two legs, but who lacks a head.
heisig_story: The pictograph hidden in this character is of someone yawning. The first stroke shows the head thrown back; the second, the arm bent at the elbow as the hand reaches up to cover the mouth; and the last two, the legs. Since yawning shows a lack of something (psychologically, interest; physiologically, sleep), the connection is plain to see.

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: To me, this hanzi looks like a person with two arms and two legs, but who lacks a head.
humanum_full_description_en:
The shape of an oracle like a man venting his mouth. The golden characters are remnant, or interpreted as " owed ." The opening of the upper part of Xiaozhuan is false, so "Shuowen" thinks that the image of the characters emerges from people. "Shuowen": "I owe it, open my mouth and realize it. It is like the form of qi coming out of people.

Oracle bone inscriptions are used as names. For example, "Collection" 914 reverses: "We owe." Another example is "Combination" 21475: "Jiawu Bu: I owe this evening..." Bronze inscriptions are also used as names.

" Oow " means yawning. Such as "Rituals. "The scholar meets the ceremony": "The gentleman owes the stretch." Zheng Xuan's note: "The will be tired if you are tired, the tired body is stretched." "Han. Sui Liang Xia Hou Jingyi Li Chuan": "So Zang disease is caused by qi in the face, and body disease is not moved by the appearance."

" Owe " also means lack and deficiency. "Ji Yun. Verification of rhyme: "Insufficient." Such as "The Family Instructions of Yan Family. "Mianxue": "Or both essays are owed, don't believe in one corner." It means that when the book is revised, there may be deficiencies in both texts, and one of them must not be trusted. Another example is Bai Juyi's "Han Shi Ye" in the Tang Dynasty: "Suddenly the season was shocking, and now forty is one year short."

The extension of " owed " means a debt . Such as "Old Tang Book. "Benji of Yizong": "After eight years of Dazhong, to four years of Xiantong, he owed more than 1,55,700 horses." "Jing Shi Tong Yan. "Guy member confessed on a poor journey abroad": "After this funeral expense, it is inevitable to owe some debts."

" Owe " also means that a part of the body is slightly upward or forward, which means more respect. For example, Chapter 76 of "The Romance of the Three Kingdoms": "Wei Junying's gate opens, and Xu Huang leaps forward, leaning forward." The first act of Cao Yu's "Thunderstorm": "(Lu Gui) is a bit hunched, and seems to be leaning forever to agree "Yes"."

Heisig constituents: lack, yawn
Heisig: The pictograph hidden in this character is of someone yawning. The first stroke shows the head thrown back; the second, the arm bent at the elbow as the hand reaches up to cover the mouth; and the last two, the legs. Since yawning shows a lack of something (psychologically, interest; physiologically, sleep), the connection is plain to see.
* As a primitive, it can mean either yawn or lack.

The shape of an oracle like a man venting his mouth. The golden characters are remnant, or interpreted as " owed." The opening of the upper part of Xiaozhuan is false, so "Shuowen" thinks that the image of the characters emerges from people. "Shuowen": "I owe it, open my mouth and realize it. It is like the form of qi coming out of people. Oracle bone inscriptions are used as names. For example, "Collection" 914 reverses: "We owe." Another example is "Combination" 21475: "Jiawu Bu: I owe this evening..." Bronze inscriptions are also used as names. " Oow" means yawning. Such as "Rituals. "The scholar meets the ceremony": "The gentleman owes the stretch." Zheng Xuan's note: "The will be tired if you are tired, the tired body is stretched." "Han. Sui Liang Xia Hou Jingyi Li Chuan": "So Zang disease is caused by qi in the face, and body disease is not moved by the appearance." " Owe" also means lack and deficiency. "Ji Yun. Verification of rhyme: "Insufficient." Such as "The Family Instructions of Yan Family. "Mianxue": "Or both essays are owed, don't believe in one corner." It means that when the book is revised, there may be deficiencies in both texts, and one of them must not be trusted. Another example is Bai Juyi's "Han Shi Ye" in the Tang Dynasty: "Suddenly the season was shocking, and now forty is one year short." The extension of " owed" means a debt. Such as "Old Tang Book. "Benji of Yizong": "After eight years of Dazhong, to four years of Xiantong, he owed more than 1,55,700 horses." "Jing Shi Tong Yan. "Guy member confessed on a poor journey abroad": "After this funeral expense, it is inevitable to owe some debts." " Owe" also means that a part of the body is slightly upward or forward, which means more respect. For example, Chapter 76 of "The Romance of the Three Kingdoms": "Wei Junying's gate opens, and Xu Huang leaps forward, leaning forward." The first act of Cao Yu's "Thunderstorm": "(Lu Gui) is a bit hunched, and seems to be leaning forever to agree "Yes"." 516 Characters

Chinese dictionary definition of words
[â‘ ]ï¼»qiÃ nï¼½
["Guangyun" goes to Jianqi, goes to Fan, Xi. ]
(1) Open your mouth and yawn when you are tired.
(2) A part of the body is slightly lifted or moved.
(3) Refers to slightly bent body.
(4) Debt. The borrower's property has not been returned or should be given but not given.
(5) Lack; insufficient.
(6) Poor, not beautiful.
(7) The extension is inferior.
(8) It is commonly said that there are defects and faults in behavior.
(9) Sometimes it also refers to human frivolousness.
(10) Worry about; miss.
(11) Uneasy.
(12) Regret. See also "worries".
(13) Dementia.
(14) Merry; decent.
